docs.lead_paragraph: Couples who are trying to have a baby should focus their efforts on the days leading up to ovulation, not on the day of ovulation itself, a new report advises. The article, in this month's issue of Obstetrics & Gynecology, suggests that the best time to have intercourse may be the day before a woman ovulates. Repeated intercourse in the five days before ovulation will probably increase the odds of conception, the article said.
docs.abstract: University of Utah researchers, reporting in Obstetrics & Gynecology, suggest that best time to try to conceive baby is five days leading up to ovulation, not day of ovulation itself; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Pregnancy in Barbie's world? Stick to playing nurse and Rapunzel, Wal-Mart shoppers say. Barbie's longtime friend, Midge -- now married and pregnant -- was removed from the shelves of Wal-Mart Stores this month after customers complained about the doll.
docs.abstract: Midge, pregnant doll from Mattel, is removed from Wal-Mart shelves because of complaints from customers; doll is part of Happy Family set that includes husband and 3-year-old son, but is sold separately, perhaps suggesting to some people a single mother (S)
docs.snippet: Pregnancy in Barbie's world? Stick to playing nurse and Rapunzel, Wal-Mart shoppers say.    Barbie's longtime friend, Midge -- now married and pregnant -- was removed from the shelves of Wal-Mart Stores this month after customers complained about the...

docs.lead_paragraph: IN times past, tombstones often told the story of a life. This example was recorded in the book ''Churchyard Literature,'' published in 1877: ''Sacred to the memory of William Beekman, jun. son of John and Mary E.G. Beekman, who died of the epidemick fever, at the Wallabought, on Long Island, 24 October, A.D. 1805, aged 11 years, 8 months, 24 days.''
docs.abstract: Brief vignettes of notable Long Island residents who died in 2002: longtime Babylon Mayor E Donald Conroy, Hempstead official Dorothy Tripp, labor market economist Sonya Kornreich, Slacke Test Boring founder Sally Ann Slacke, Sikh leader Harbhajan Singh, outspoken civil rights figure Ralph Watkins, former Old Westbury Mayor Eleanor A Simpson, Fire Island conservation activist George Biderman, Long Island Community Foundation leader Helen P McIntyre, Westbury Friends School founder Eloise Hicks, Stony Brook University medical school dean Marvin Kuschner, Art League of Long Island benefactor Elisabeth Sloan Pratt Livingston, Long Island Weekly Voice editor and publisher William Brazier and wife, Alice Marie Brazier, World War II pilot Francis S Gabreski, retired Molloy College co-founder Sister Helen Therese Nyberg, landscape architect Carolee Swick and Long Island Builders Institute co-founder Kalman Klein; photos (L)
